1.10.1.title: Pre-Spud Meeting
1.10.1.content:
A Pre-Spud Meeting shall be held before commencing drilling operations:

**Purpose:**
- Ensure all parties understand the well plan
- Identify well control hazards and mitigations
- Confirm equipment and personnel readiness
- Establish communication protocols

**Attendees:**
- Operator Representative
- Drilling Supervisor
- Toolpusher
- Drillers
- Mud Engineer
- Key service company personnel
- Shore-based support as needed

**Agenda Items:**
- Well objectives and program overview
- Geological prognosis and hazards
- Pore pressure and fracture gradient predictions
- Casing program and setting criteria
- BOP configuration and testing requirements
- Kick tolerance by hole section
- Kill procedures to be used
- Emergency response procedures
- Communication requirements
- Roles and responsibilities

**Documentation:**
- Meeting minutes distributed to all parties
- Action items tracked to completion
- Attendance recorded

1.10.2.title: Bridging Documents
1.10.2.content:
Bridging documents align Operator and Contractor procedures:

**Purpose:**
- Identify differences between Operator and Contractor procedures
- Specify which procedures take precedence
- Fill gaps where procedures are silent
- Ensure clear understanding by all parties

**Topics to Address:**
- Shut-in procedures (hard vs soft shut-in, timing)
- Kill method selection
- Notification requirements
- Authority levels
- Equipment testing frequencies
- Training requirements
- Reporting requirements

**Process:**
1. Compare Operator and Contractor procedures
2. Identify differences and gaps
3. Agree on approach for each item
4. Document agreements
5. Communicate to all relevant personnel
6. Review when procedures change

**Documentation:**
- Signed bridging document
- Distributed to all supervisory personnel
- Available at point of use

1.10.3.title: Daily Meetings
1.10.3.content:
Daily meetings maintain awareness and coordination:

**Morning Meeting:**
- Review of previous 24 hours
- Current well status and barriers
- Plan for next 24 hours
- Well control considerations for planned operations
- Equipment status
- Personnel issues
- Weather/environmental factors
- Safety moment

**Attendees:**
- OIM or delegate
- Drilling Supervisor
- Toolpushers (both crews)
- Operator Representative
- Key department heads

**Documentation:**
- Meeting minutes or daily report
- Key decisions recorded
- Actions assigned and tracked

1.10.4.title: Shift Handovers
1.10.4.content:
Effective handovers are critical for well control safety:

**Driller Handover:**
- Current operation and status
- Well control parameters (MW, TVD, pressures)
- Any abnormal observations
- Equipment status or issues
- Planned operations
- Specific watch points

**Supervisor Handover:**
- Detailed well status
- Operations in progress
- Outstanding issues
- Planned activities and timing
- Personnel matters
- Communications with shore

**Handover Requirements:**
- Face-to-face communication (not just written)
- Time for questions and clarification
- Walk-through of key equipment if needed
- Written record maintained

**Never handover during:**
- Active well control operations
- Critical operations requiring continuity
- Uncertain well conditions

1.10.5.title: Pre-Job Meetings (Toolbox Talks)
1.10.5.content:
Pre-job meetings shall be held before critical operations:

**When Required:**
- Before each hole section
- Before tripping operations
- Before cementing operations
- Before any operation with well control implications
- After significant changes to plan
- Following any well control event

**Content:**
- Planned operation step-by-step
- Well control hazards and mitigations
- Kick indicators to watch for
- Actions if kick indicators observed
- Roles during the operation
- Communication protocol
- Stop work criteria

**Participation:**
- All personnel involved in the operation
- Questions encouraged
- Understanding verified

1.10.6.title: Post-Event Debriefs
1.10.6.content:
Following any well control event, a debrief shall be conducted:

**Hot Debrief (Immediately after event):**
- Conduct while events are fresh
- Focus on what happened and what worked/didn't work
- Capture initial lessons
- Identify immediate improvements
- No blame - learning focus

**Formal Investigation (Level 2 and 3 events):**
- Root cause analysis
- Contributing factors identified
- Timeline reconstruction
- Data review and analysis
- Corrective actions identified
- Lessons learned documented

**Sharing:**
- Lessons shared across organization
- Industry sharing where appropriate
- Procedures updated if needed
- Training updated to reflect lessons

1.10.7.title: Documentation Requirements
1.10.7.content:
Comprehensive documentation supports well control management:

**Required Documentation:**
- Drilling program and well control contingencies
- Kill sheets (current for well conditions)
- BOP test records
- Drill records and results
- Training records
- Meeting minutes
- Handover logs
- Daily drilling reports
- Mud reports
- BOP function test records

**Event Documentation:**
- Incident reports
- Investigation reports
- Corrective action tracking
- Lessons learned database

**Retention:**
- As required by regulation (typically well life plus 5-10 years)
- Accessible for audit and review
- Backed up and secure
